The fair, the bright, the great, alas!  are fall'n;</br>Nipt in the bloom of beauty, wit, and youth;</br>Death's undistinguish'd prey.  Shall I complain</br>(When such th' establish'd ordinance of heav'n)</br>If SICKNESS at my bosom lay the siege;</br>A worm to them!  and to their light a shade,</br>Ungilded with one beam, which melted down</br>The tear soft-trickling o'er the orphan'd cheek:</br>We all must dye!  Our every pulse that beats,</br>Beats toward eternity, and tolls our doom.

Fate reigns in all the portions of the year.</br>The fruits of Autumn feed us for disease:</br>The Winter's raw inclemencies bestow</br>Disease on death.  While Spring, to strew our herse,</br>Kindly unbosoms weeping in their dews,</br>Her flowry race!  and Summer (kinder still)</br>With the green turf and brambles binds our grave.

We not alone have end.  In measur'd time</br>(So heav'n will'd) together with their snows,</br>The everlasting hills shall melt away:</br>This solid globe dissolve, as ductile wax</br>Before the breath of Vulcan; like a scroll</br>Shrivel th' unfolded curtains of the sky;</br>Thy planets, Newton, tumble from their spheres;</br>The moon be perisht from her bloody orb;</br>The sun himself, in liquid ruin, rush</br>And deluge with destroying flames the globe—</br>Peace then, my soul, nor grieve that Pope is dead.

If 'ere the tuneful spirit, sweetly strong,</br>Spontaneous numbers, teeming in my breast,</br>Enkindle; O, at that exalting name,</br>Be favourable, he propitious now,</br>While in the gratitude of praise, I sing</br>The works and wonders of this man divine.

I tremble while I write. — His lisping muse</br>Surmounts the loftiest efforts of my age.</br>What wonder?  when an infant, he apply'd</br>The loud Papinian trumpet to his lips,</br>Fir'd by a sacred fury, and inspir'd</br>With all the God, in founding numbers sung</br>"Fraternal rage, and guilty Thebes' alarms."

Sure at his birth (things not unknown of old)</br>The Graces round his cradle wove the dance,</br>And led the maze of harmony:  the Nine,</br>Prophetick of his future honours, pour'd</br>Plenteous, upon his lips, Castalian dews;</br>And Attic bees their golden store distill'd.</br>The soul of Homer, sliding from its star,</br>Where, radiant, over the poetic world</br>It rules and sheds its influence, for joy</br>Shouted, and bless'd the birth:  the sacred choir</br>Of poets, born in elder, better times,</br>Enraptur'd, catch'd the elevating sound,</br>And roll'd the glad'ning news from sphere to sphere.

Imperial Windsor!  on thy brow august,</br>Superbly gay, exalt thy tow'ry head</br>And bid thy forests dance, and nodding wave</br>A verdant testimony of thy joy:</br>A native Orpheus warbling in thy shades.

O listen to Alexis' tender plaint!</br>How gently rural!  without coarseness, plain;</br>How simple in his elegance of grief!</br>A shepherd, but no clown.  His every lay</br>Sweet as the early pipe along the dale,</br>When hawthorns bud, or on the thymy brow</br>When all the mountains bleat and vallies sing.</br>Soft as the nightingale's harmonious woe,</br>In dewy even-tide, when cowslips drop</br>Their sleepy heads, and languish in the breeze.

Next in the critic-chair survey him thron'd,</br>Imperial in his art, prescribing laws</br>Clear from the knitted brow, and squinted sneer;</br>Learn'd, without pedantry; correctly bold,</br>And regularly easy.  Gentle, now,</br>As rising incense, or descending dews,</br>The variegated echo of his theme:</br>Now, animated flame commands the soul</br>To glow with sacred wonder.  Pointed wit</br>And keen discernment form the certain page.</br>Just, as the Stagyrite; as Horace, free;</br>As Fabian, clear; and as Petronius gay.

But whence those peals of laughter shake the sides</br>Of decent mirth?  Am I in fairy-land?</br>Young, evanescent forms before my eyes,</br>Or skim, or seem to skim; thin essences</br>Of fluid fight; Zilphs, Zilphids, Elves and Gnomes;</br>Genij of Rosicruce, and Ladies' Gods!—</br>And, lo, in shining trails Belinda's hair,</br>Bespangling with dishevel'd beams the skies,</br>Flames o'er the night.  Behind, a satyr grins</br>And, jocund, holds a glass, reflecting, fair,</br>Hoops, crosses, mattadores; beaux, shocks, and belles,</br>Promiscuously whimsical and gay.</br>Tassoni, hiding his diminish'd head,</br>Droops o'er the laughing page:  while Boileau</br>With blushes cover'd, low beneath the desk.

More mournful scenes invite.  The milky vein</br>Of amorous grief devolves its placid wave</br>Soft-streaming o'er the soul, in weeping woe</br>And tenderness of anguish.  While we read</br>Th' infectuous page, we sicken into love,</br>And languish with involuntary fires.</br>The zephyr, panting on the silken buds</br>Of breathing violets; the virgin's sigh,</br>Rosy with youth, are turbulent and rude,</br>To Sappho's plaint, and Eloisa's moan.

Heav'ns!  what a flood of empyreal day</br>My aking eyes involves!  A Temple soars,</br>Rising like exhalations, on a mount,</br>And wide its adamantine valves expands.</br>Three monumental columns, bright in air,</br>Of figur'd gold, the center of the quire</br>With lustre fill, Pope on the mldmost shines</br>Betwixt his Homer and his Horace plac'd,</br>Superior by the hand of justice.  Fame,</br>With all her mouths th' eternal trumpet swells,</br>Exulting at his name; and, grateful, pours</br>The lofty notes of never-dying praise,</br>Triumphant, floating on the wings of wind,</br>Sweet o'er the world th' ambrosial spirit flies</br>Diffusive, in its progress wid'ning still,</br>"Dear to the earth, and grateful to the sky."</br>Fame owes him more than e'er she can repay:</br>She owes her very Temple to his hands;</br>Like Ilium built; by hands no less divine!

Attention, rouze thyself!  the master's hand,</br>(The master of our souls!)  has chang'd the key,</br>And bids the thunder of the battle roar</br>Tumultuous.  Homer, Homer is our own!</br>And Grecian heroes flame in British lines.</br>What pomp of words!  what nameless energy</br>Kindles the verse; invigours every line;</br>Astonishes, and overwhelms the soul</br>In transport tost!  When fierce Achilles raves,</br>And flashes, like a comet, o'er the field,</br>To wither armies with his martial frown.</br>I see the battle rage; I hear the wheels</br>Careering with their brazen orbs!  The shout</br>Of nations rolls (the labour of the winds)</br>Full on my ear, and shakes my inmost soul.</br>Description never cou'd so well deceive:</br>'Tis real!  Troy is here, or I at Troy</br>Enjoy the war.  My spirits all on fire,</br>With unextinguish'd violence, are born</br>Above the world, and mingle with the Gods.</br>Olympus rings with arms!  the firmament</br>Beneath the light'ning of Minerva's shield,</br>Burns to the center:  rock the tow'rs of heav'n.</br>All nature trembles save the throne of Jove.

To root excesses from the human-breast;</br>Behold a beauteous pile of ethicks rise;</br>Sense, the foundation; harmony, the walls;</br>(The Dorique grave, and gay Corinthian join'd)</br>Where Socrates and Horace jointly reign.</br>Best of Philosophers!  of Poets too</br>The best!  He teaches thee thyself to know:</br>That virtue is the noblest gift of heav'n:</br>"And vindicates the ways of GOD to Man."</br>O hearken to the Moralist polite!</br>Enter his school of truth; where Plato's self</br>Might preach; and Tully deign to lend an ear.

Last see him waging with the fools of rhyme</br>A wanton, harmless war.  Dunce after Dunce</br>Beaux, Doctors, Templars, Courtiers; Sophs and Cits,</br>Condemn'd to suffer life.  The motley crew,</br>Emerging from oblivion's muddy pool,</br>Give the round face to view; and shameless front</br>Proudly expose; till laughter have her fill.
Born to improve the age, and cheat mankind</br>Into the road of honour! — Vice again</br>The gilded chariot drives: — for He is dead!

I saw the sable barge, along his Thames,</br>In slow solemnity beating the tide,</br>Convey his sacred dust! — Its swans expir'd:</br>Wither'd, in Twit'nam bow'rs, the laurel-bough;</br>Silent, the Muses broke their idle lyres:</br>Th' attendant Graces check'd the sprightly dance,</br>Their arms unlock'd, and catch'd the starting tear;</br>And Virtue for her lost defender mourn'd!

Each volume a Bodleian! — Yet this man,</br>This mortal man (which leads me to my theme)</br>With pain embarass'd, all his tedious days,</br>And head-achs rack'd, the boundless sea of wit</br>Spread o'er the world.  Thus (his own poet tells)</br>Minerva from the labouring brow of Jove,</br>Sprung radiant:  hurl'd the pointed spear of sense</br>Against the breast of ignorance and vice:</br>Athens inspir'd, and taught her bards to sing.

But am I 'wake?  or in Ovidian realms,</br>And Circe holds the glass?  What odious change,</br>What metamorphose strikes the dubious eye?</br>Ah, whither is retir'd the scarlet wave,</br>Mantling with health which floated through the Cheek,</br>From the strong summer-beam imbib'd?  And where</br>The vernal lilly's softly-blended bloom?</br>The forehead roughens to the wond'ring hand.</br>Wide o'er the human-field, the body, spreads</br>Contagious war, and lays its beauties waste.</br>As once thy breathing harvest, Cadmus, sprung,</br>Sudden, a serpent-brood!  an armed crop</br>Of growing chiefs; and fought themselves to death.</br>One black-incrusted bark of gory boils</br>One undistinguish'd blister, from the soal</br>Of the sore foot, to the head's sorer crown.</br>JOB'S punishment!  With patience like his own,</br>O may I exercise my wounded soul;</br>And cast myself upon his healing hand,</br>Who bruiseth at his will, and maketh whole.

Ah, too, the lustre of the eyes is fled!</br>Heavy and dull, their orbs neglect to roll,</br>In motionless distortion stiff and fix'd:</br>Till by the trembling hand of watchful age</br>(A weeping matron, timorous to affright,</br>And piously fallacious in her care,</br>Pretending light offensive, and the sun)</br>Clos'd; and, perhaps, forever!  ne'er again</br>To open on the sphere, to drink the day,</br>Or (worse!)  behold Ianthe's face divine,</br>And wonder o'er her charms. — But yet forebear,</br>O dare not murmur:  'tis heav'n's high behest.</br>Tho' darkness through the chambers of the grave</br>This dust pursue, and death's sad shade involve;</br>E'er long, the filial-light himself shall shine;</br>(The stars are dust to him, the sun a shade)</br>These very eyes, these tunicles of flesh,</br>Ev'n tho' by worms destroy'd, shall see my GOD,</br>And, seeing, ne'er remember darkness more,</br>Environ'd with eternity of day.

Tho', at their visual entrance, quite shut out</br>External forms, forbidden, mount the winds,</br>Retire to Chaos, or with night commix:</br>Yet, fancy's mimick work!  ten thousand shapes</br>Antick and wild, rush sweeping o'er my dreams,</br>Irregular and new:  as pain or ease</br>The spirits teach to flow, and in the brain</br>Direction diverse hold.  Gentle and bright</br>As hermits, sleeping in their mossy cells,</br>Lull by the fall of waters!  by the rills</br>From Heliconian cliffs devolv'd:  or where,</br>Thy antient river, Kishon, sacred stream!</br>Soft-murmurs on their slumbers:  peace within,</br>And conscience, ev'n to ecstasy sublim'd</br>And beatific vision.  Sudden, black,</br>And horrible as murderers; or haggs,</br>Their lease of years spun out, and signed bond</br>Full-flashing on their eyes; the gulf, beneath,</br>Mad'ning with gloomy fires; and heav'n, behind</br>With all her golden valves for ever clos'd.

Now in Elysium lap'd, and lovely scenes,</br>Where honeysuckles rove, and eglantines,</br>Narcissus, jess'min, pinks, profusely wild,</br>In every scented gale Arabia breathe:</br>As blissful Eden fair; the morning-work</br>Of heav'n, and Milton's theme!  where innocence</br>Smil'd, and improv'd the prospect. — Now, anon,</br>By Isis' favourite flood supinely laid,</br>In tuneful indolence, behold the bards</br>(Harps in each hand, and laurel on each brow)</br>A band of demy-gods, august to sight,</br>In venerable order sweetly rise,</br>Encircled by the muses, who have trod</br>In measur'd pace its banks, forever green,</br>Enamel'd from their feet!  Harmonious notes,</br>Warbled to Dorique reeds, to Lesbian lyres,</br>Or Phrygian minstrelsie, steal on the ear</br>Enamour'd with variety:  and loud</br>The trumpets shrilling clangours fill the sky</br>With silver melody — Now, happier still!</br>Round thy Italic cloisters, musing slow,</br>Or in sweet converse with thy letter'd sons,</br>Philosophers, and Poets, and Divines,</br>Enjoy the sacred walk, delighted; QUEEN'S!</br>Where Addison and Tickle lay inspir'd,</br>Inebriated from the classic springs,</br>And tun'd to various-sounding harps the song,</br>Sublime, or tender; humorous, or grave</br>Quaffing the Muses' nectar to their fill.

Momental happiness! — I know not how,</br>I know not where, the midnight howl of wolves,</br>The dragon's yell, the lion's roar, astound</br>My trembling ear.  Ha!  down a burning mount</br>I plunge deep, deep:  sure Vulcan's shop is here—</br>Hark, how the anvils thunder round the dens</br>Flammivomous!  What?  are those chains to bind</br>This skeleton?  the Cyclops must be mad:</br>Those bolts of steel, those adamantine links</br>Demand Typhaeus' strength to burst. — Away—</br>Venus and Mars — beware. — In giddy whirls</br>I ride the blast and tow'ring through the storm</br>Enjoy the palace of the morn.  The sun</br>Resigns the reins of Phlegon to my hands:</br>His mane waves fire:  he scorches me to dust:</br>Avaunt, thou fiend! — I'll hurl thee down the deep</br>Of heav'n, with bolted thunder, and enwrapt</br>With forky light'ning. — Now staggering I reel,</br>By murderers pursu'd:  my faithless feet</br>Scarce shift their pace or down rushing amain,</br>I cease to recollect my steps, and roll</br>Passive on earth. — Sure, 'twas Astolpho's horn</br>Pour'd on my ear th' annoying blast:  Or else</br>That rapid giddiness o'erturns my brain,</br>Which, whilom, plagu'd the sons of Calydon,</br>When cruel, fair Callirhoe enrag'd</br>Coresus, priest of Bacchus!  and his vows,</br>With impious scorn, neglected.  Old the tale,</br>Yet worthy to be told in modern song.

High in Achaia, splendid from afar,</br>A city flourish'd; Calydon its name,</br>Wash'd by Evenus' chalky flood; the seat</br>Of Meleager, from the slaughter'd boar</br>Glorious.  A virgin here, amazing, shone,</br>Callirhoe the fair:  her father's boast!</br>For, ah, she never knew a mother's smile;</br>Nor learn'd what happiness from marriage springs.</br>In flow'r of youth, and purer than the snow</br>Which, with a silver circle, crown'd the head</br>Of the steep neighbour mountain; but averse</br>To Hymen's rites, the lovely foe of man,</br>O why will beauty, cruel to itself</br>No less than others, violate the laws</br>Which nature dictates, and itself inspires!

A thousand lovers, from th' Olenian hill,</br>From rough Pylene, and from Pleuron's towr's,</br>Their passion pleaded.  But Coresus, chief,</br>The Calydonian priest of Bacchus, form'd</br>By Venus' self for love; in beauty's pride;</br>Young, bounteous affable.  What tender arts,</br>What winning carriage, and respectful suit,</br>Almost to zealous adoration swell'd,</br>Did he not practise?  But in vain.  And now</br>Drew near the Orgial festival, and rites</br>Lyaean.  Poor Coresus, to approve</br>The wonders of his love and dear regard,</br>By scorn unquench'd, unabated by neglect</br>(In hopes to soften her, at least adorn)</br>Presented to this murdress of his peace</br>The ritual ornaments) by virgins worn</br>Upon the solemn feast.  The ivy-spear,</br>With winding green and viny foliage gay,</br>Curl'd by his hand:  a mitre for the head,</br>Curious aumail'd with imitated grapes,</br>Of blushing rubies form'd:  the pall of lawn,</br>Flow'r'd with the conquests of the purple God:</br>The cista, silver; and the cymbals, gold:</br>And piny torch (O were it Hymen's!)  ting'd</br>With spicy gums, to feed the ready flame.

Open'd the festival — Loose to the winds,</br>Dishevel'd, bare, the virgins give their necks</br>And wanton hair.  Evoe!  they, mad'ning, cry,</br>And shake their torches.  Evoe!  Io!  rends</br>The air, and beats the echoing vault of heav'n.</br>The hills, the vales with Io!  Evoe!  ring.

The temple opens to the sacred throng;</br>When foremost enters, as in dress and charms,</br>Callirhoe, so in speed.  Their lovers wait,</br>With burning expectation, to enfold</br>His beauteous mistress each.  High on a throne</br>Coresus blaz'd in jewels and in gold,</br>More charming in himself.  Quick with his eye</br>He catch'd Callirhoe; and, descending, clasp'd</br>With eager transport her reluctant waist.</br>A thousand vows he breath'd, and melting things</br>He spoke and look'd; but to the rocks and wind.</br>What cou'd he more?  Yes more he did:  for what,</br>What can't a lover, like Coresus, do?</br>Neglectful of his dignity, he sunk</br>(Still love disdains what dignity demands,</br>O'er Jupiter himself supreme) he sunk,</br>And trembled at her feet, with prostrate zeal,</br>As to his God.  He dy'd upon her hand</br>With sighing languishment:  He gaz'd his soul</br>At every ardent glance into her eyes</br>Most eloquently silent!  O'er his cheek</br>The gushing tears in big, round drops, diffus'd</br>The dews of passion, and the brain's soft show'r,</br>Potent to warm the most obdurate breast,</br>Tho' cold as marble.  Idle were his tears,</br>His glances, languishment and prostrate zeal.

Disdainful — frowning:  "Hence, (she cry'd) not</br>To interrupt my progress in the rites</br>With thy capricious rudeness.  Shall the priest</br>The mysteries of Bacchus thus profane,</br>In his own temple too?  And rather pay</br>To Venus his devotion, than his God?"</br>Then haughty as away the turn'd; he grasp'd</br>Her knees; upon her garments flowing train</br>Shivering he hung:  and with beseeching eyes,</br>Thus, from th' abundance of his heart, complain'd.

"If pity be no stranger to thy breast,</br>(As sure it should not to a breast like thine,</br>Soft as the swanny down!)  relenting, hear</br>In feelingness of spirit, mildly lend</br>Attention to the language of my heart,</br>Sick with o'er-flowing tenderness and love.</br>I love thee with that innocence of truth,</br>That purity of passion, and desire</br>Unutterable, of bequeathing up</br>My heart, my life, my all into thy hands,</br>Into thy gentle custody; — that all,</br>My heart, my life, are bitterness and weight</br>Of agony without thee.  Since I first,</br>(By Bacchus' self I swear,) beheld that face,</br>And nameless magick of those radiant eyes,</br>All the foundation of my peace gave way:</br>While hopes and fears rose up in bosom-war</br>To desolate the quiet of my days.</br>Thy dear idea was my fancy's dream;</br>It mingled with my blood; and in my veins</br>Throb'd, undulating, as my life were stung.</br>I live but on the thought of thee; my breast</br>Bleeds in me, with distress to see thee frown.</br>O smile; by thy dead mother's reverend dust,</br>By all thy bowels are most fond of, smile,</br>And chase these heavy clouds of grief away.</br>I beg by Bacchus; for his sake be kind."

Here, interrupted by the swelling storm</br>Of passion labouring in his breast, his words</br>Gave way to sighs and tears, to speak the rest.</br>She in contempt'ous derision, smil'd,</br>To which her frowns were innocent:  and thus:</br>"Thy staggering pow'r, and thee I scorn alike:</br>Him I despise, for chusing thee his priest;</br>Thee, for thy arrogance, and courtship vile."
Indignant he, in wrathful mood (alarm'd</br>More at his God revil'd, than scorn for him)</br>First casting on the ground his mitred-crown,</br>With hands and eyes uplifted, ardent, pray'd.

"Offspring of Jove, Evoe Lyaeus, hear!</br>If e'er these hands with ivy wreaths thy brow</br>Circled, and twining tendrils of the vine:</br>If e're my grateful tongue, big with thy praise,</br>Evoe Lyaeus!  Io Bacchus!  sung:</br>If e'er thy servant on thy altars pour'd,</br>Copious, the purple wave of offer'd wine;</br>And, busy, fed the consecrated fire</br>With fat of ass, or hog, or mountain-goat;</br>Devoutly lavish in the sacrifice:</br>Avenge thy priest; this cursed race destroy:</br>Thy honours violated thus, avow;</br>Till they confess this staggering pow'r a God."
He pray'd. — Loud peals of thunder shook the fane:</br>The image, nodding, his petition seal'd;</br>And Bacchus gave the Calydonian race</br>To madness, and unutterable woes.

The frantick crowd, as if with wine opprest,</br>And the strong spirit of the flaming grape,</br>To and fro' reel, and stagger to and fro',</br>In dithyrambic measures, wild, convolv'd.</br>They toss their cymbals, and their torches shake,</br>Shrieking; and tear their hair, and gash their flesh,</br>And howl, and foam, and wheel the rapid dance</br>In giddy maze:  with fury then o'erborn,</br>Enthusiastick whirling in despair,</br>Flat, drop down dead; and heaps on heaps expire.

Amaz'd, confounded at the raging pest,</br>The venerable fathers, in debate,</br>To speed enquiring deputies, resolv'd,</br>To high Dodona's grove; with vocal oaks</br>Umbrageous, aged, vast, the struggling day</br>Excluding:  the prime oracle of Greece!
Obsequious, they haste:  enquire:  return:</br>And thus the counsels of the God disclose.

"The rage of Bacchus for his injur'd priest,</br>Coresus, by Callirhoe's scorn repuls'd,</br>Your city wastes:  and with funereal fires</br>Your streets shall redden, formidably bright,</br>Till by Coresus' hand the cruel maid</br>A sacrifice be offer'd up:  or one,</br>Free, uncompell'd, embrace the destin'd steel,</br>Devoted in her stead; and bleed for her.</br>So you'll appease the God; the plague be stay'd."

They said.  Staring affright, and dumb amaze</br>The fathers seize:  but chief, Aeneus, thee,</br>Callirhoe's old miserable sire!</br>Tenfold affliction to the grave weighs down</br>Thy silver'd hairs.  But fate and heav'n require.

Soon through the city spred the news, and soon</br>Wounded Callirhoe's ear.  Her spindle drops</br>Neglected from her hand.  Prone on the floor,</br>She falls, she faints; her breath, her colour fled:</br>Pale, cold and pale.  Till, by assisting care,</br>The fragrant spirit hovers o'er her lips,</br>And life returning streams in rosy gales;</br>Rekindled only to despair.  She knew</br>The virgins envy'd; and the injur'd youth</br>Stung with her scorn wou'd wanton in her wounds,</br>Nor one one offer up the willing breast</br>A victim for her Life.  And now the crowd,</br>Impatient of their miseries, besiege</br>The marble portal; burst the bolted gates;</br>Demand Callirhoe; furious to obey</br>The oracle, and pacify the God.

What pangs, unhappy maid, thy bosom tear,</br>Sleepless, and sad?  relenting now too late,</br>Thy stubborn cruelty.  Coresus' charms</br>Blaze on thy mind; his unexampled love</br>His every virtue rising to thy thought.</br>Just in his fury, see the pointed steel</br>Waves, circling, o'er thy throbbing breast:  He strikes,</br>He riots in thy blood with dire delight;</br>Insatiate!  He gluts his heart of rage</br>With thy warm, gushing life, and death enjoys,</br>Redoubling wound on wound, and blow on blow.

Thus pass'd her hours.  And now the dewy morn</br>The mountains tip'd with gold, and threatned day.</br>Without the city gates, a fountain wells</br>Its living waters, clear as shining glass:</br>Haunt of the nymphs!  A cypress' aged arms</br>Threw round a venerable gloom, and seem'd</br>Itself a grove.  An altar on the brink</br>Convenient rose:  for holy custom wills</br>Each victim to be sprinkled with its streams,</br>New from pollution, worthier of the God.</br>Fierce for the sacrifice, Coresus here</br>Waited; and, stimulated with revenge,</br>He curs'd and chid the lazy-circling hours</br>Too slow, as if injurious to his hate.

But soon the gath'ring crowd and shouts proclaim </br>Callirhoe near.  Her weeping damsels lead</br>The destin'd offering, lovely in distress,</br>And sparkling through her tears.  A myrtle crown</br>With roses glowing, and selected green,</br>Th' ambrosial plenty of her golden hair</br>Entwine:  in looks, a Venus; and a Grace in motion.</br>Scarce the flow'rs of sixteen springs </br>The fields had painted, since Aeneus first</br>Fondled his babe, and blest her on his knee.</br>Ev'n mountain-clowns, who never pity knew,</br>Relented, and the hardest heart wept blood,</br>Subdu'd by beauty, tho' the fatal source</br>Of all their misery.  What tumults then</br>Roll in thy breast, Coresus!  while thy hands</br>The purifying waters on her head</br>Pour'd trembling; and the sacred knife unsheath'd!

Wiping the silver-streaming tears away,</br>She with a look nor chearful, nor dismay'd,</br>But languishingly sweet, her ruby lips</br>Soft-op'ning, thus began:  "Father and friends.</br>Wound me not doubly with your tender grief:</br>I was not born alone for you.  My life</br>I gladly offer for my country's weal:</br>'Tis glory thus to die.  Receive my blood,</br>Dear native soil!  O may it health restore</br>And peace; and Bacchus' wrath be now appeas'd.</br>And thou Coresus whom I most have wrong'd,</br>Look not so fiercely on me, while the steel</br>My once-lov'd bosom launces; drop a tear;</br>One sigh in mercy heave, and drop one tear,</br>And I will thank thee for thy blow.  For, oh</br>I never hated thee:  but female pride,</br>Our sex's curse!  forbade me to comply,</br>Too easy won! — Then pity me, Coresus,</br>O pity; and if possible, forgive,"

He answer'd not.  But ardent, snatch'd the knife,</br>And running o'er her beauties, strangely wild,</br>With eyes which witness'd huge dismay and love;</br>"Thus, thus I satisfy the Gods!"  he cry'd,</br>And bury'd in his heart, in his own heart,</br>The guilty blade.  Then, reeling to her arms</br>He sunk, and groaning, "O Callirhoe." — dy'd.

Heav'n rings with shouts, "Was ever love like this?"</br>Callirhoe shriek'd; and from the gaping wound,</br>Quick as the lightning's wing, the reeking knife</br>Wrench'd:  in an agony of grief and love,</br>Her bosom piercing, on her lover fell</br>And sigh'd upon his lips her life away.</br>Their blood uniting in a friendly stream,</br>With bubbling purple stain'd the silver flood;</br>Which to the fountain gave Callirhoe's name.</br>Thus fell Callirhoe; lovelier in her death,</br>Than cruelty of life; and stay'd the plague.

Now starting from this wilderness of dreams,</br>I wake from fancy'd into real woe.</br>Pain emptys all her vials on my head,</br>And steeps me o'er and o'er.  Th' envenom'd shirt</br>Of Hercules enwraps my burning limbs</br>With dragon's blood:  I rave and roar like him,</br>Writhing in agony.  Devouring fires</br>Eat up the marrow, frying in my bones.</br>O whither, whither shall I turn for aid?—</br>Methinks a Seraph whispers in my ears,</br>Pouring ambrosia on them, "Turn to God;</br>So peace shall be thy pillow, ease thy bed,</br>And night of sorrow brighten into noon.</br>Let the young cherub PATIENCE, bright-ey'd</br>And rosy-finger'd PRAY'R, combining hold</br>A sure dominion in thy purpos'd mind,</br>Unconquer'd by affection." — I receive</br>The mandate as from heav'n itself. — Expand</br>Thyself, my soul, and let them enter in.

Come, smiling angel, PATIENCE, from thy seat;</br>Whether the widow's cot, or hermit's cell.</br>By fasting strong, and potent from distress;</br>Or midnight-student's taper-glimmering roof,</br>Unwearied with revolving tedious tomes.</br>O come, thou Panacaea of the mind!</br>The manna of the soul!  to every taste</br>Grateful alike:  the universal balm</br>To sickness, pain, and misery below.</br>She comes!  she comes!  she dissipates the gloom;</br>My eyes the opens, and new scenes unfolds</br>(Like Moses' bush; tho' burning, not consum'd)</br>Scenes full of splendour, miracle, and God.</br>Behold, my soul, the martyr-army, who</br>With holy blood the violence of fire</br>Quench'd, and with lingring constancy fatigu'd</br>The persecuting flame:  or nobly stop'd</br>The lion's mouth, and triumph'd in his jaws.</br>Hark, how the virgin white-rob'd confessors</br>Chaunt Hallelujahs to the rack; as dear</br>And pleasing to the ear of God, as hymns</br>Of angels on the resurrection-morn,</br>When all the host of heaven Hosanna sing!</br>Yet further; lift thy eyes upon the cross,</br>A bleeding Saviour view, a dying God!</br>Earth trembles; rend the rocks, creation groans:</br>The sun, asham'd, extinguishes the day</br>All nature suffers with her suffering Lord.</br>Amidst this war of elements, serene,</br>And as the sun-shine brow of patience, calm,</br>He dies without a groan, and smiles in death.</br>Shall martyrs, virgins, nay, thy Saviour bleed</br>To teach thee Patience?  and yet bleed in vain?</br>Forbid it, reason; and forbid it, heav'n.</br>No; suffer:  and in suffering, rejoice.</br>Patience endureth all, and hopeth all.

HOPE is her daughter then.  Let Hope distill</br>Her cordial-spirit, as Hybla-honey sweet,</br>And healing as the drops of Gilead-balm.</br>Cease to repine, as those who have no Hope;</br>Nor let Despair approach thy darkest hour.</br>Despair!  that triple-death!  th' imperial plague!</br>Th' exterminating angel of th' accust,</br>And sole disease of which the damn'd are sick,</br>Kindling a fever hotter than their hell—</br>O pluck me from Despair, white-handed Hope!</br>O interpose thy spear and seven-fold shield</br>Betwixt my bosom and the fiend!  detrude</br>This impious monster to primaeval hell;</br>To its own dark domain.  But light my soul,</br>Imp'd with thy glittering wings, to scenes of joy,</br>To health and life, for health and life are thine:</br>And fire imagination with the skies.

But whence this confidence of Hope?  In thee,</br>And in thy blood, my Jesus!  (Bow, O earth!</br>Heav'n bends beneath the name, and all its sons,</br>The hierarchy!  drop low the prostrate knee,</br>And sink, in humble wise, upon the stars)</br>Yes, on thy blood and name my hope depends,</br>My hope?  nay, worlds on worlds depend on thee;</br>Live in thy death, from thy sepulchre rise.</br>Thy influential vigour reinspires</br>This feeble frame:  dispells the shade of death;</br>And bids me throw myself on God in prayer.

A christian soul is God's beloved house:</br>And Pray'r the incense which perfumes the soul:</br>Let armies then of supplications rise,</br>Besiege the golden gates of heav'n, and force,</br>With holy violence, a blessing down</br>In living streams.  If Hezekiah's pray'r</br>The sun arrested in his prone career,</br>And bade the shadow ten degrees return</br>On Ahaz-dial, whirling back the day:</br>Pour out thyself, my soul!  with fervent zeal,</br>With over-flowing ardour, and with faith</br>Unwavering.  To assist me, and to swell</br>My fainting spirits to sublime desires,</br>Wou'd Taylor from his starry throne descend,</br>Fear wou'd have end:  for by his sacred aid,</br>To live were happiness, and gain to die.—</br>No:  let him still adorn his starry throne,</br>Well-merited by labours so divine:</br>For, lo!  the man of God, and friend of man,</br>Theron, the purest breast, and warmest heart,</br>Flys on the wings of charity and love</br>To join me in the saving-Task, and raise</br>My weaker powers with his abundant zeal:</br>Pure, sweet, and glowing as the incens'd fires,</br>Of, Solomon, thy golden-altar, fann'd</br>By wings of Cherubins into a flame:</br>Till on the skies the aromatick gale</br>In pyramids of fragrance softly stole,</br>A grateful offering to the throne of grace.

Still, tho' I feel these succours from the skies</br>In operation mighty!  still remain</br>Inferior aids behind:  terrestrial stores</br>Medicinal:  the instruments of God.</br>For God created the PHYSICIAN!  God</br>Himself on earth our great Physician!  spread</br>O'er Sick and Weak shadowing, his healing wings,</br>Each miracle a cure! — Before disease,</br>Offspring of sin, infested human-kind,</br>In Paradise, the vegetable seeds</br>Sprung from their maker's hand, invigorate-strong</br>With Med'cin.  He foresaw our future ills;</br>Foreseeing, he provided ample cure;</br>Fossils, and simples:  Solomon, thy theme,</br>Nature's historian:  wisest of the wise!</br>Tho' Paradise be lost; the tree of life</br>In med'cin blooms:  then pluck its healing fruits,</br>And with thanksgiving eat; and, eating, live.

Ev'n pagan wisdom bade her sons adore,</br>As one, the God of physick and the day,</br>Fountain of vegetation and of life,</br>Apollo, ever blooming, ever young.</br>And from his art immortal!  Thus, of yore,</br>The prime of human race from heav'n deduc'd</br>The bright original of physick's pow'r:</br>And, nor unjustly, deem'd that he who sav'd</br>Millions from death, himself shou'd never die.

An instrument of various pipes and tubes,</br>Veins, arteries, and sinews, organiz'd,</br>Man, when in healthy-tune, harmonious wakes</br>The breath of melody, in vocal-praise,</br>Delighting earth and heav'n!  discordant oft</br>As accident, or time, or fate prevail,</br>This human-organ scarce the bellows heaves</br>Of vital-respiration; or in pain,</br>With pauses sad.  What art divine shall tune</br>To order and refit this shatter'd frame?</br>What fingers touch into a voice again?</br>Or musick re-inspire?  Who, but the race</br>Of Paean?  who but Physick's saving sons?—</br>But something yet beyond the kindly skill</br>Of Paean's sons, disease, like mine, demands:</br>Nepenthe to the soul, as well as life.

O for a mother's watchful tenderness,</br>And father's venerable care! — But they</br>In life immortal, gather endless joys,</br>Reward of charity, of innocence,</br>Of pleasing manners, and a life unblam'd!</br>The tears of poverty and friendship oft</br>Their modest tombs bedew; where Eden's stood</br>(Ituna 'clep'd by bards of old renown,</br>Purpled with Saxon and with British blood)</br>Laves the sweet vale that first my pratling Muse</br>Provok'd to numbers, broken as the ruins</br>Of Roman towers which deck its lofty banks,</br>And shine more beauteous by decay,—</br>But hark!  What musick glads my ear?  'Tis Theron's voice.</br>Theron a father, mother:  both, a friend!—</br>Pain flies before his animating touch:</br>The gentle pressure of his cordial hand,</br>A burning mountain from my bosom heaves!</br>What wonders, sacred friendship, flow from thee!</br>One period from a friend enlivens more,</br>Than all Hippocrates and Galen's tomes,</br>Than all the med'cines they unfold.  I feel</br>Myself renew'd!  not only health, but youth,</br>Rolls the brisk tide, and sparkles at my heart.</br>As the live-atoms of Campanian wines</br>Dance in the virgin crystal, and o'erlook</br>With glorifying foam, the nectar'd brim;</br>Smiling and lending smiles to social wit,</br>The jocund hearth, and hospitable board.

Friendship is a religion, from the first</br>The second-best:  it points, like that, to heav'n.</br>And almost antidates, on earth its bliss.</br>But Vice and Folly never friendship knew:</br>Whilst Wisdom grows by friendship still more</br>Her fetters, are a strong defence; her chains,</br>A robe of glory; Ophir gold, her bands;</br>And he who wears them wears a crown of joy.

Friendship's the steel, which struck emits the sparks</br>Of candour, peace, benevolence, and zeal;</br>Spreading their glowing seeds — A holy fire</br>Where honour beams on honour, truth on truth;</br>Bright as the eyes of angels and as pure.</br>An altar whence two gentle-loving hearts</br>Mount to the skies in one conspiring blaze</br>And spotless union.  'Tis the nectar-stream</br>Which feeds and elevates seraphic love—</br>Health is disease, life death, without a friend.
